Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Haitao Liu of the University of Pittsburgh is developing a new lithography method based on DNA nanotechnology. Lithography is used to make integrated circuits such the ones used in personal computers and cellphones. However, conventional lithography is approaching its resolution limit imposed by light diffraction. This project will develop a DNA-based lithography that is both high resolution and low cost by exploiting the programmability of DNA nanostructures. In addition, this grant will also initiate a summer research program that will train undergraduate students from non-Ph.D. granting institutions.

This project will test the hypothesis that the local chemical environment (e.g., base sequence and chemical modification) within a DNA nanostructure can effectively modulate the rate of surface reactions to result in high-resolution pattern transfer. The proposed work aims to understand the chemical mechanism of this novel pattern transfer process and based on which to develop a general strategy to control surface reaction kinetics using DNA nanostructures. The effect of local chemical environment on the reaction kinetics will be studied by varying the base sequence and the chemical functionalization of a DNA nanostructure template. These experimental studies will be coupled with molecular dynamics simulations to provide a molecular scale understanding of the effect of DNA nanostructure on the adsorption of reactive precursors and their subsequent reactions on the surface. Using the chemistry developed here, one will be able to fabricate arbitrary-shaped patterns with unprecedented resolution, down to sub-10 nm. More significantly, because the mechanism of the pattern transfer is widely applicable to supramolecular templates, in general, this work could have broad impact on the field of bottom-up nanofabrication.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is to explore if and how DNA nanostructures can be used as template for nanostructure fabricaiton.

Altough DNA is best know as the genetic material for life, recently it has been used to prepare nanometer sized objects through controlled folding of DNA strands. This approach, called DNA nanotechnology, made it possible to make nanostructure with controlled size and shape. This research explores the possibility to use these DNA nanostructure to pattern other materials. The long term goal is to develop lithography methods that are based on DNA templates. This approach has the potential to be low cost and scalable to large substrates.

In the past 3.5 years, we have developped a number of patterning approaches for inorganic and organic substrates. We have used DNA nanostrucure as the template to pattern monolayer thick films, called self-assembled monolayers. We have showed that DNA nanostructures can be converted to carbon structures of the same shape. We have used DNA nanostructure as a 'stamp' to imprint its shape onto polymer substrates.

These results showed that DNA nanostructures can be used in very harsh chemical environments that previously though were incompatible with DNA. For example, we heated DNA nanostructure to 1000 degrees and show that although the organic component in DNA decomposes at this temperature, the carbon residue still maintain its shape. We also showed that DNA nanostructures are compatible with atomic layer deposition of aluminum oxide materials. The oxide-coated DNA nanostructure showed significant improvement in its mechanical stability. They can be used as a nanoscale 'stamp' to print nanoscale features onto polymers. Due to the oxide coating, these 'stamps' can be used multiple times without mechanical damage.

This project trained 7 graduate students and 6 undergraduate students. Three of the graduate students already obtained their Ph.D. The project supported the development of a new lab module for the undergraduate analytical chemistry lab at Pitt. We also filed a patent application that describes the fabrication of carbon nanostructures from DNA template.
